qas.question: What symptoms do you have with IBS?

answers.text: abdominal discomfort relieved by defecation and unusual stool (diarrhea or constipation) for at least 3 days a week over the previous 3 months

qas.question: How can symptoms be managed with IBS?

answers.text: a combination of dietary changes, soluble fiber supplements, and/or medications

qas.question: What is another possible cause of unusual stool?

plausible_answers.text: a combination of dietary changes, soluble fiber supplements, and/or medications such as loperamide or codeine

qas.question: How can symptoms of bile acid malabsorption be managed?
How many patients with SeHCAT have bile acid malabsorption?

plausible_answers.text: bile acid malabsorption diagnosed with an abnormal SeHCAT test.

qas.question: What is the diagnosis for patients with unusual stool?

context: Another possible cause of <b3_0>diarrhea<b3_0/> is <a0_0><b5_0>irritable bowel syndrome<b5_0/><a0_0/> (IBS), which usually presents with <a1_0>abdominal discomfort relieved by defecation and unusual stool (diarrhea or constipation) for at least 3 days a week over the previous 3 months<a1_0/>. Symptoms of diarrhea-predominant IBS can be managed through <a2_0><b4_0>a combination of dietary changes, soluble fiber supplements, and/or medications<a2_0/> such as loperamide or codeine<b4_0/>. <b6_0>About 30% of patients<b6_0/> with diarrhea-predominant IBS have <b7_0>bile acid malabsorption diagnosed with an abnormal SeHCAT test.
